awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2019:  Leveraging Quantitative Genetic Mapping Data for Discovery of Novel Regulatory DNA in Solanum lycopersicum
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF National Plant Genome Initiative Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2019. The fellowship supports a research and training plan in a host laboratory for the Fellow who also presents a plan to broaden participation in biology. The title of the research and training plan for this fellowship to Grace A. Mason is "Leveraging Quantitative Genetic Mapping Data for Discovery of Novel Regulatory DNA in Solanum lycopersicum". The host institutions for the fellowship are the University of California, Davis/University of Minnesota, Twin Cities and the sponsoring scientists are Drs. Siobhan Brady and Chad Myers. 

Traditionally, crop improvement relies solely on selective breeding for desired traits. While successful, this laborious methodology reduces breeders' ability to quickly predict traits based on genetic variation as well as improve available breeding resources. To allow for faster and more systematic breeding, this project aims to systematically test genetic variation within the tomato genome for their effects on gene expression and on selected root architecture phenotypes. Potential regulatory variants will then be tested first for the ability to influence gene expression and then for its effect on plant root architecture phenotypes, traits that are generally understudied and could be of potential use to tomato breeders. The broader impacts of the project include providing hands-on training in basic research for local high school and undergraduate students from diverse backgrounds as well educating the general public about tomato breeding and how modern technologies can allow for non-transgenic crop improvement. Training objectives include acquiring skills in the use of quantitative genetics and computational science and tool development in an economically relevant crop plant.

Variation in regulatory DNA is thought to be a major factor for phenotypic variation in wild species as well as domestication of cultivated crop plants. Enhancers, a type of regulatory DNA, regulate target gene expression in a spatiotemporal manner and can be relatively distal to their target genes, thus making them difficult to characterize. In animal systems, hundreds of enhancers are well-characterized and have been linked to target genes. In plants, despite recent efforts to identify genome-wide regulatory elements, only thirteen enhancers in four plant species have been directly linked to target genes. Of these, only variation in the tb1 enhancer in Zea mays (corn) is demonstrably linked to domestication and crop improvement. To address this disparity, the overall goal of this project is to discover allele-specific plant enhancers and link them to their target genes. Specifically, regulatory enhancer elements will be identified in Solanum lycopersicum (tomato) using novel computational methods for genetic mapping data with a specific focus on root architecture traits. The research will take advantage of several diverse genetic resources, including an extensive catalog of domesticated tomato accessions, existing quantitative trait data sets, as well as a genetically divergent set of isogenic introgression lines. Large-scale enhancer assay techniques will be used to yield allele-specific regulatory regions linked to root architecture phenotypes. While there has been intense effort to characterize the regulatory landscape in several cultivated plants, these experiments will be the first to directly test plant-based association mapping variants using large-scale sequencing technologies. Sequencing data from this project will be archived and publicly available through the National Center for Biotechnology Information (NCBI) GEO and Probe databases. Additionally, all CRISPR-Cas9 constructs will be made available by request and through Addgene, the nonprofit global plasmid repository (https://www.addgene.org/). Software and analysis scripts will be made available through GitHub.

Keywords: tomato, gene expression, genetic variation, regulatory DNA, enhancer element, root architecture, quantitative genetics

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Variation in regulatory DNA is thought to be a major factor driving phenotypic variation in wild species as well as domestication of cultivated plants. Enhancers, a type of regulatory DNA sequence, regulate target gene expression in a spatiotemporal manner and can be relatively distal to their target genes, thus making them difficult to characterize. In animal systems, hundreds of enhancers are well-characterized and have been linked to target genes. In plants, despite recent efforts to identify genome-wide regulatory elements, only 13 bona fide enhancers in four plant species have been directly linked to target genes 1. Of these 13 enhancers, only variation in the tb1 enhancer in maize is demonstrably linked to domestication and crop improvement. Strikingly, there are no known bona fide root-specific enhancers. To address this disparity, I set out to discover allele-specific plant enhancers and link them to their target genes.

I identified potential regulatory enhancer elements in Solanum lycopersicum (tomato) using genetic mapping data with a specific focus on seedling root architecture traits. To do so, I took advantage of a diverse catalog of domesticated and wild tomato accessions2 to perform a genome wide association mapping study (GWAS). Using genetic variants I identified in my study, I used a large-scale enhancer assay technique (massively parallel reporter assay) to yield allele-specific regulatory regions linked to root architecture phenotypes3. While there has been intense effort to characterize the regulatory landscape in several cultivated plants, the experiments summarized here are the first to directly test plant-based association mapping variants using large-scale sequencing technologies.

To test non-coding genetic variation directly, I performed a GWAS. Here, I used diverse tomato lines from the Varitome project2. This panel of accessions consists of S. lycopersicum cv. cerasiforme, S. pimpinellifolium, and domesticated S. lycopersicum landraces. In collaboration with Wolfgang Busch's group, I assayed the following traits: primary root length, total lateral root length, width the of the root system, standard deviation of width, and shape of the root system. After performing association mapping, I found 29 unique significant loci across these traits (Figure 1). Because a significant locus may not be the causal locus, I also identified loci each significant variant was tightly linked to (i.e. often inherited together). As such, I identified a total of ~3,000 variants that were included for further testing.

To test candidate loci from my GWAS, I used a modified version of the cell-culture based massively parallel reporter assay (MPRA) modified for plants3.  MPRA takes advantage of known enhancer properties by creating constructs with a minimal promoter of interest and placing DNA fragments of interest upstream of a barcoded reporter gene (Figure 2). If a DNA fragment has enhancer properties, it will activate expression of the reporter gene and thus RNA-seq is used to quantitatively measure a putative enhancer's activity (Figure 2).

After DNA fragment synthesis of GWAS variant sequences, I assembled them into a plant-specific MPRA vector. After assembly, the input MRPA libraries were sequenced to determine the frequency of each assayed fragment. Next, the GWAS variant libraries were transfected into root protoplasts and RNA sequencing was performed to determine the activity of each GWAS variant fragment relative to the input. Fold-enrichment of the reference and alternate alleles was then compared. If I observed one allele with significantly greater activity than the alternate allele, the genetic variant influences enhancer strength. Indeed, I found five promising candidate loci that show significantly different enhancer activity compared to their partner alleles (Figure 3). Currently, we are validating these results in planta.  

In today's highly politicized world, use of genetically modified organisms in the food supply is exceedingly controversial. One strategy to address this controversy is to characterize natural genetic variation in crops and their wild ancestors to create precise breeding strategies. One potential source of valuable genetic variation to precisely drive traits of interest is regulatory DNA. Changes in regulatory DNA are often tissue- or condition-specific; therefore, they are less deleterious and potentially useful for improved breeding strategies. No experiments performed in plants, let alone a cultivated crop, have systematically tested genetic variation for gene regulatory activity. Indeed, I found that that there are allelic differences for variants derived from an association mapping study.  I am optimistic that my results will be useful to others studying regulatory DNA, as well as in the role of enhancers in determining evolution within Solanum species.

 

 

References

1.         Weber, B., Zicola, J., Oka, R. & Stam, M. Plant Enhancers: A Call for Discovery. Trends in Plant Science 21, 974–987 (2016).

2.         Mata-Nicolás, E. et al. Exploiting the diversity of tomato: the development of a phenotypically and genetically detailed germplasm collection. Horticulture Research 7, 1–14 (2020).

3.         Jores, T. et al. Identification of Plant Enhancers and Their Constituent Elements by STARR-seq in Tobacco Leaves[OPEN]. The Plant Cell 32, 2120–2131 (2020).
